greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Write the numbers from 1 to n^2 consecutively in n rows of length n; let c(k) = number of primes in k-th column; a(n) = minimal c(k) for gcd(k,n) = 1.
comment: Conjectured to be always positive for n>1.
Note that a(n) is large when phi(n), the number of integers relatively prime to n, is small and vice versa. - _T. D. Noe_, Jun 10 2003
The conjecture is true for all n <= 40000.
reference: See A083382 for references and links.
link: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n=1..2000
example: in which columns 1 and 3 contain 2 and 3 primes; therefore a(4) = 2.
mathematica: Table[minP=n; Do[If[GCD[c, n]==1, s=0; Do[If[PrimeQ[c+(r-1)*n], s++ ], {r, n}]; minP=Min[s, minP]], {c, n}]; minP, {n, 100}]
program: a083414 n = minimum $ map c $ filter ((== 1) . (gcd n)) [1..n] where
c k = sum $ map a010051 $ enumFromThenTo k (k + n) (n ^ 2)
xref: Cf. A083415 and A083382 for primes in rows.
A084927 generalizes this to three dimensions.
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Jun 10 2003
ext: More terms from _Vladeta Jovovic_ and _T. D. Noe_, Jun 10 2003
